senses.de: Something that makes it difficult to think or pay attention
senses.ex: Sorry, I didn't catch that - the noise from next door was a real distraction.

Tips.title: Negative Context
Tips.description: Often used when something negatively affects focus, especially during tasks requiring concentration.
Tips.example: The construction noise outside was a huge distraction during my exam.

Tips.title: Degree Varies
Tips.description: Can imply different scales of disruption, from minor annoyances to complete loss of attention.
Tips.example: A fly buzzing around is a minor distraction, but loud music could derail your study session.

senses.de: Something that amuses or entertains you so that you do not think about problems or worries
senses.ex: She listens to music as a distraction from her troubles.

Tips.title: Positive Escape
Tips.description: Usually describes an enjoyable break from stress or routine, often implying relief or comfort.
Tips.example: The comedy show was a welcome distraction from the stress of work.

Tips.title: Temporary Relief
Tips.description: Refers to a short-term diversion, not a solution to one's problems or worries.
Tips.example: Playing video games provided a necessary distraction from his anxiety.

senses.de: An activity that diverts the mind from tedious or serious concerns; a recreation or pastime
senses.ex: Reading is a good distraction from the cares of life.

Tips.title: Active Engagement
Tips.description: In a psychological sense, implies an active engagement in an alternative activity for mental rest.
Tips.example: Taking up painting as a distraction can be a therapeutic way to unwind.

Tips.title: Refocus Strategy
Tips.description: Used in academic or therapeutic contexts to discuss strategies for redirecting attention.
Tips.example: Educators often use puzzles as distractions to manage classroom behavior.

senses.de: A mental state of being drawn or turned to one side; a divided attention
senses.ex: Distraction is a common symptom in young children with ADHD.

Tips.title: Attention Split
Tips.description: Highlights the splitting of attention that may lead to inefficiency in completing tasks.
Tips.example: With constant distractions from his phone, he couldn't finish his homework.

Tips.title: Cognitive Symptom
Tips.description: In medical or psychological discussion, it points to a symptom affecting cognitive function.
Tips.example: Distraction is often discussed as a symptom in patients with concentration disorders.

Deflection.wordDefinition:
Deflection refers to redirecting the focus of a conversation or argument away from a particular topic or issue.

Deflection is about shifting blame or attention away from a specific topic, while distraction refers to something that causes your attention to stray from what you're trying to accomplish.

Disruption.wordDefinition:
Disruption refers to something that interrupts or changes the normal flow of events.

It can be intentional or unintentional, but it often creates a significant impact on the situation. For example, a protest can cause a disruption by blocking traffic and preventing people from going about their daily activities.

Disruption is a significant interruption of normalcy, while distraction is a mere diversion from what you should be doing.

Disturbance.wordDefinition:
A disturbance is something that interrupts or bothers you.

To summarize, a distraction is an external force that diverts your attention while a disturbance is an external force that causes irritation or interruption.

Diversion.wordDefinition:
Distraction and diversion are both words used to describe a situation where someone's attention is redirected from something else.

A diversion is a deliberate redirection of someone's attention. It's often used to avoid a difficult or uncomfortable situation.

For example, if someone is having a heated argument and one person tries to change the subject to avoid the argument, it would be a diversion.

Distraction refers to something that pulls your attention away from what you're doing, while a diversion is a deliberate attempt to redirect someone's attention.

Hindrance.wordDefinition:
Distraction and hindrance are two words that describe obstacles or barriers that prevent someone from doing something.

Hindrance refers to something that actively blocks or prevents you from doing something. For example, if you're trying to exercise but there's a big, heavy couch in the way, that couch is a hindrance because it's physically stopping you from moving.

Overall, distractions are things that can make it harder to do something, while hindrances are things that actively prevent you from doing something.

Interruption.wordDefinition:
Interruption is when something or someone externally stops you from doing what you were doing. For example, if you were in a meeting and your boss walked in and started talking to you, your attention would be interrupted from the meeting.

Distraction is something that you have control over, something you can avoid whereas interruption is something that may come unannounced and disrupt your current task.

Obfuscate.wordDefinition:
Obfuscate means to make something unclear or confusing. It's like trying to hide the truth or make it difficult for someone to understand what's really going on.

For example, if a politician uses complicated language to avoid answering a question directly, they're obfuscating the issue.

The main difference is that a distraction is something that takes your attention away from something else, while obfuscation is intentionally making something unclear or confusing.

A distraction can be unintentional, while obfuscation is always deliberate.

Obstruction.wordDefinition:
An obstruction is something that physically blocks or hinders your progress. For example, if a tree falls across the road, it obstructs the path and makes it difficult or impossible for cars to pass.

A distraction is a mental interruption, while an obstruction is a physical barrier.

Distractions can occur anywhere - at school, work, or home - while obstructions typically occur out in the world, such as on a road or a construction site.

Preoccupation.wordDefinition:
Preoccupation refers to being deeply absorbed or overly focused on something. This could be something like being preoccupied with a problem you're trying to solve.

A distraction is an external force that takes your attention away from what you're supposed to be doing, while preoccupation is something that you are internally focused on.

To help you focus, norepinephrine creates a sort of tunnel vision, blocking out surrounding distractions,

quotes.Text: Successful people maintain a positive focus in life no matter what is going on around them. They stay focused on their past successes rather than their past failures, and on the next action steps they need to take to get them closer to the fulfillment of their goals rather than all the other distractions that life presents to them.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Jack Canfield

quotes.Text: I feel like I'd invested so much in the physical side of my life: running marathons - I brought a SEAL into my house - I have a trainer. But I've invested very little on the inner work, and in a world of distractions, I felt like to have the whole picture, I really had to spend a little time alone and work on being present.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Jesse Itzler

quotes.Text: You know how a lot of people say, 'I lose myself in music,' or 'I like to escape,' but I want my music to be more of an awakening. I want it to make people to be aware of life; I don't want my music to be a distraction. I want to light a path.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Jhene Aiko

quotes.Text: You have a number of choices. You could continue to always fight against people who are really distractions. They're people in the cheap seats of life. Or you can do what you went there to do.
quotes.Title: American Judge
quotes.Name: Clarence Thomas

quotes.Text: All my life, since the time I was little, has been a long distraction. At least that is the way some people want to perceive it, but for me, it's given me a lot of strength.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Hope Solo

quotes.Text: Music was always the distraction, so it was the obvious choice to pursue. My dad always said to find a job I love to do, that way it wouldn't feel like a job. So I did that.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Jason Mraz

quotes.Text: Nothing is quite so emotional and passionate as what goes on inside of a family. People are driven to distraction by a father or a mother or a husband. Or a child.
quotes.Title: British Actress
quotes.Name: Helen Mirren

quotes.Text: I have wandered all my life, and I have also traveled; the difference between the two being this, that we wander for distraction, but we travel for fulfillment.
quotes.Title: English Poet
quotes.Name: Hilaire Belloc

quotes.Text: A stronger focus on quality public policymaking and less distraction of personalities would be a sufficient and important contribution I can make.
quotes.Title: Australian Politician
quotes.Name: Jay Weatherill

quotes.Text: I've trained all my life not to be distracted by distractions.
quotes.Title: American Entertainer
quotes.Name: Nik Wallenda
